Article Title: After phones and laptops, Google is bringing Gemini AI to this everyday device
Article Text:
What Gemini on Google TV means for users

Google TVs to get upgraded hardware

At CES 2025 , Google has announced that it is bringing Gemini AI-powered features to Google TVs this year. The company unveiled a suite of new AI-powered features for Google TV , designed to make interacting with your television more intuitive and helpful.“At this year's CES, we shared a preview of new AI capabilities for Google TV that use our Gemini models to make interacting with your TV more intuitive and helpful. You and your family will be able to gather together and have a natural conversation with your TV,” the company said.Leveraging the power of Google's Gemini models, these features aim to transform select Google TV models into a conversational and interactive hub for entertainment, information, and smart home control.“This will make searching through your media easier than ever, and you will be able to ask questions about travel, health, space, history and more, with videos in the results for added context,” Google added.Moreover, the Gemini model on Google TV will also enable users to create personalised artwork with their family, control their smart home devices while the TV is in ambient mode, and even get a summary of the day’s news.These new features are expected to roll out later this year on select Google TV devices, including from Sony, Hisense and TCL. Notably, Google rolled out Gemini-powered features to the Google TV Streamer.As per a report by Android Police, Google TV is also getting a hardware upgrade such as far-field microphones for hands-free voice control. Google TVs may ditch the need for a remote control with the integration of far-field microphones. This allows users to interact with Google Assistant naturally, just like with a Google Home speaker.These Google TVs will also get proximity sensors that will detect when users approach the TV, triggering an on-screen hub with personalised widgets displaying information like weather, news, and commute updates.
Article Summary: Google has announced that it is bringing Gemini AI-powered features to Google TVs this year. These features aim to transform select Google TV models into a conversational and interactive hub for entertainment, information, and smart home control. Google TVs will also get proximity sensors that will detect when users approach the TV, triggering an on-screen hub.

Article Text:

The acquisition of the 75-year-old CDI, which has a client base including several Fortune 500 companies, gives TCE eight US-based engineering centers and complements company's existing strengths.

What TCE said on the acquisition of CDI

Tata Consulting Engineers (TCE) has acquired US-based CDI Engineering Solutions , formerly Comprehensive Designers Inc (CDI). Part of the Tata Group , Tata Consulting Engineers is a design, engineering, and project management consultancy company. Tata Consulting Engineers or TCE has acquired Comprehensive Designers Inc with the aim to enter the North American market .The financial terms of the deal have not been disclosed.The combined organization aims to provide integrated solutions addressing critical global challenges, including clean energy transition, decarbonization, and resilient infrastructure.TCE’s global delivery platform will now include CDI’s eight engineering centres in the US.TCE stated that the acquisition is a "deliberate step" to expand its global reach and expertise. “The acquisition of CDI marks a deliberate step towards expanding TCE’s global footprint and scaling its expertise… With its expertise and a client base that includes several Fortune 500 companies, CDI’s capabilities complement TCE’s strengths in engineering design and project management,” TCE said in a statement.TCE Managing Director and CEO Amit Sharma said that the combined entity will be a "competitive entity capable of delivering exceptional value to clients" and addressing global priorities like energy transition and sustainable infrastructure. CDI President Steve Karlovic highlighted the shared commitment to engineering excellence and sustainability, emphasizing the growth opportunities for employees.TCE, originally founded in 1962 as Tata Ebasco (a joint venture between Tata Group and US-based Ebasco Services Inc.), became a wholly owned subsidiary of Tata Sons in 1968. In fiscal year 2024, TCE's consolidated revenue was Rs 1,406 crore (approximately $170 million USD), with India accounting for roughly 60% and domestic government clients contributing about 35%, according to ICRA. The company employs over 6,000 people.

Withings Omnia smart mirror: How is it different



French consumer electronics company Withings has unveiled a concept mirror named Omnia at CES 2025 . This smart mirror combines health tracking , AI assistance , and telehealth capabilities . Additionally, AI chatbots integrated into health tech emerged as a growing trend in 2024, with major brands like Oura, Whoop, and Fitbit exploring these technologies.Withings plans to offer demos at CES 2025, which may provide insight into whether Omnia is a legitimate product or just another example of CES health tech hype. Regardless of whether it becomes a tangible product, Omnia reflects the direction in which health tech is headed.Apart from this, Withings offers smartwatches, smart scales, connected blood pressure cuffs, smart thermometers, and even a noninvasive sleep tracker that fits under a mattress. The company has previously debuted products like an at-home urinalysis device for toilets and scales that analyze nerve health through the feet. It has also incorporated telemedicine features , such as cardiologist-reviewed EKG results in its FDA-cleared ScanWatch.

Article Title: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman breaks silence a year after his failed firing: 'They f*cked me and the company'
Article Text:
The firing that led to series of resignations

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman revealed inheriting a "complete mess" and a company "on fire" after his dramatic return as chief executive, he shared in a Bloomberg interview published on Sunday.Altman, who was abruptly fired and then rehired within five days last November, revealed that the situation deteriorated daily after his return, citing mounting government investigations and what he characterized as former board members leaking "fake news" to the press."All those people that I feel like really fucked me and fucked the company were gone, and now I had to clean up their mess," Altman told Bloomberg, referring to the aftermath of the leadership crisis that saw most of the original board members depart.The turmoil triggered a series of high-profile departures throughout 2024, including co-founder Ilya Sutskever, who had initially voted for Altman's removal, and superalignment team co-lead Jan Leike. Both joined competitor Anthropic, along with John Schulman, another OpenAI co-founder who departed in August. Chief Technology Officer Mira Murati also left the company in September.The November 2023 crisis began when the board claimed Altman "was not consistently candid in his communications," though specific details were never disclosed. The decision sparked an employee revolt, with nearly all staff threatening to quit unless Altman was reinstated.Only one board member from the original group that voted for Altman's removal, Quora CEO Adam D'Angelo, remains at OpenAI. The company, which began as a nonprofit in 2015, is now reportedly in discussions with California's attorney general's office about transitioning to a for-profit structure.
Article Summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman says he inherited a "complete mess" and a company "on fire" after his dramatic return as chief executive. Altman was abruptly fired and then rehired within five days last November. The turmoil triggered a series of high-profile departures, including co-founder Ilya Sutskever.

Article Title: How Google may have solved one of the biggest AI 'problems’
Article Text:
What is “peak data” and how it is a problem for AI industry

What is inference-time compute and how it works

The performance of an AI model relies on one important thing: data. Recently, OpenAI cofounder Ilya Sutskever declared that the AI industry has reached “peak data”, suggesting that all useful data present on the internet has been exhausted for training AI models. However, Google seems to have found a solution to this problem.“Peak data” is a term used to describe the amount of available useful data to train an AI model. The AI industry is facing a " peak data " challenge wherein all useful data has already been used for training AI models.Since all the high-quality data readily available on the internet has already been used to train existing AI models, newer models might not show significant improvements over their predecessors because they're not learning from substantially new or better information.However, Google DeepMind researchers are optimistic, pointing to a promising solution: inference-time compute , as per a report by Business Insider.This technique allows AI models to tackle complex tasks by breaking them down into smaller, manageable prompts. Each step involves a new inference request, creating a chain of reasoning where the model only progresses after solving each part correctly.This process leads to higher-quality outputs, especially in tasks with clear answers, like math problems. The breakthrough lies in using these improved outputs as fresh training data.Google DeepMind researchers proposed this method in August, suggesting an “iterative self-improvement loop” where enhanced outputs are fed back into the model for further training. This approach could bypass the “peak data” problem and fuel continued AI development.Reportedly, early results are promising, with models like OpenAI's o1 and DeepSeek V3 demonstrating significant improvements. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella expressed confidence in inference-time compute, calling it “another scaling law” for enhancing AI capabilities.“So you have pre-training, and then you have effectively this test-time sampling that then creates the tokens that can go back into pre-training, creating even more powerful models that then are running on your inference,” he said."That's I think a fantastic way to increase model capability," Nadella added.
Article Summary: The AI industry is facing a " peak data " challenge wherein all useful data has already been used for training AI models. Google DeepMind researchers are optimistic, pointing to a promising solution: inference-time compute. This technique allows AI models to tackle complex tasks by breaking them down into smaller, manageable prompts.

Article Title: Airbnb blocked 74,000 bookings worldwide on New Year eve in 2023, and says will follow same measures in 2024 as well
Article Text:
How Airbnb checks ‘party’ booking

Planning a New Year's Eve party at an Airbnb? Think again. The company is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. This technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location. While implemented worldwide, the technology will specifically target the US, UK, Australia, Canada, France, Puerto Rico, Spain and New Zealand. Last New Year's Eve, Airbnb blocked 74,000 such bookings.High-risk bookings will be blocked or redirected to alternative accommodations. Short holiday getaways (one to three nights) in entire homes will also be restricted, and guests booking entire homes will be required to agree to a "mandatory anti-party attestation." "If a booking is identified as higher risk, the guest will either be blocked from booking, or redirected to alternative accommodations on the platform," the company said.Guests will also be required to accept mandatory anti-party attestation. "Guests who can make reservations will need to confirm that they understand that disruptive and unauthorized parties are not allowed on Airbnb, and they face suspension or removal from the platform if they violate this policy," said the company.Airbnb also has a 'Neighborhood Support Line' for local communities to report urgent issues, like a party in progress, at a home they believe is listed on Airbnb.Airbnb's efforts to curb disruptive parties started in 2019 with a ban on "party houses," followed by stricter measures in 2020 due to the pandemic. In 2022, the company permanently banned large parties worldwide following several violent incidents at Airbnb rentals, including a shooting in Pittsburgh that resulted in two deaths and eight injuries.
Article Summary: Airbnb is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. The technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location.

With millions of people turning to social media for skincare advice, many end up buying expensive products that might not even work for their skin.The device looks at proteins in your skin to figure out how it's aging and what it needs. Article Title: YouTuber Ankush Bahuguna on 40-hour Digital Arrest: Can’t believe this has happened to me ... I have lost money, I have lost ...
Article Text:
YouTuber Ankush Bahuguna shared his distressing ordeal with a 40-hour digital arrest scam on Instagram, where scammers falsely accused him of serious crimes and extracted personal information, causing financial loss and mental distress. Bahuguna shared his story to raise awareness about such sophisticated digital scams.

Poll What’s a Bigger Concern with Digital Arrests by Scammers? Privacy Invasion Financial Loss

The big mistake he made

Linked to money laundering, drug trafficking and other serious crimes

"Not everybody reacts the same way to panic"

YouTuber Ankush Bahuguna recently shared a harrowing experience on Instagram, revealing how he became a victim of a 40-hour digital arrest scam . After a three-day absence from social media, Bahuguna described how scammers held him hostage, causing him financial loss and significant mental distress. “I have been missing from social media and everywhere for the last three days, I was held hostage by some scammers for 40 hours… I have lost money, I have lost my mental health to this, I can’t believe this has happened to me,” Bahuguna said in an Instagram post.Bahuguna explained he received an automated international call (+1 prefix) claiming a cancelled courier delivery. “It seemed like an international number. I picked it up without thinking much. It was an automated call that said your courier delivery had been cancelled. Press zero for support,” he explained. Pressing zero connected him to someone who alleged his name was linked to a package containing illegal items seized by customs, supposedly destined for China. Despite denying any involvement, the scammers insisted his Aadhar number and personal details were connected, placing him under “digital arrest.”The situation escalated rapidly. The scammers accused Bahuguna of money laundering, drug trafficking, and other serious crimes, claiming he was a “prime suspect” in a “national case” with an active arrest warrant. “I was then told I don't have enough time to go to the police station and he will do me a favour by connecting directly to the police station,” Bahuguna explained.They then transferred him to a WhatsApp video call with someone posing as a police officer in uniform, further intensifying his panic.Isolating him from the outside world, the scammers instructed Bahuguna to cut off all communication and turn off his devices. They extracted personal information and placed him under “self-custody,” keeping him on a continuous video call for 40 hours, preventing him from contacting anyone. They even directed him to a bank for suspicious transactions, which thankfully failed due to the branch being closed. It was only when a friend contacted him, suspecting fraud, that Bahuguna realized he had been scammed.Bahuguna shared his story to raise awareness and prevent others from experiencing similar ordeals. He emphasized the importance of understanding how panic can affect individuals differently and urged against judging victims. He also stressed the increasing prevalence of such scams and the need for vigilance against unexpected calls or messages, especially those involving threats or accusations of illegal activity. “Not everybody reacts the same way to panic. Instead of calling this stupid, make people around you aware of it,” he said in a follow-up comment.This incident highlights the sophisticated tactics used in digital scams, including exploiting personal information, psychological manipulation, and creating a sense of urgency and fear. The rise of digital platforms has unfortunately made it easier for scammers to target individuals, underscoring the importance of public awareness and caution. Bahuguna’s experience serves as a crucial reminder to stay informed and protect oneself from these increasingly common schemes.
Article Summary: YouTuber Ankush Bahuguna shared his distressing ordeal with a 40-hour digital arrest scam on Instagram. Scammers falsely accused him of serious crimes and extracted personal information, causing financial loss and mental distress. He shared his story to raise awareness about such sophisticated digital scams.

Article Text:

Why DOJ is opposing Donald Trump’s request

What TikTok says

The US Department of Justice (DOJ) has asked the Supreme Court to reject President-elect Donald Trump 's request to delay a law that could ban TikTok or force its sale by January 19, 2025, reports Reuters. A law passed in April 2024 requires TikTok’s Chinese parent company, ByteDance , to sell its US assets or face a ban. If the law takes effect, TikTok will be removed from Apple and Google app stores. While existing users can keep using the app, but over time, it will stop working as updates and support are blocked.Last week, Trump argued that he should have until after he takes office on January 20 to find a "political solution" to the issue.The DOJ said TikTok has not proven it is likely to win the case, which is necessary for a delay. It also emphasized concerns about national security , stating that China could use TikTok to gather sensitive data on Americans and conduct harmful operations.Interestingly, Trump’s current support for TikTok marks a shift from 2020, when he tried to ban the app and force its sale due to concerns over its Chinese ownership.TikTok is fighting back, saying the law violates free speech under the First Amendment. The company also pointed out that other Chinese-owned apps like Shein and Temu have not been targeted, suggesting TikTok is being singled out because of its content, not its data practices.TikTok's future in the US now depends on how the Supreme Court rules and whether Biden extends the deadline. The court will hear arguments about the case on January 10.Earlier, ByteDance has rejected selling TikTok, citing Chinese export regulations from 2020 that restrict the sale of its core algorithmic technology. Without this algorithm, any acquisition would lack the innovations that define TikTok's success. Despite these challenges, investors like Steven Mnuchin and Frank McCourt have expressed interest in buying the platform. Republican Rep John Moolenaar remains optimistic that Trump may facilitate an American acquisition to keep TikTok operational in the US.
